item.title: Europe Must Use Its Economic “Bazooka” Against the US
item.description: Nothing is ever final with US President Donald Trump, who recently threatened new tariffs against the European Union and its member states for their digital regulations and taxes. The EU must finally stand up for itself by activating its most powerful tool against economic pressure, the Anti-Coercion Instrument.

item.title: Why Are Markets Ignoring the Obvious About America?
item.description: Given that Donald Trump’s agenda should concern those who hold capital, many are wondering why there has been so little resistance to his administration from markets and Big Business. Six possible explanations stand out – and none of them bodes well for the long term.

item.title: How America Could Lead the Next Era of Digital Innovation
item.description: As the gatekeepers for the mobile app market, Apple and Google have amassed significant, persistent market power with which to extract monopoly rents from consumers and business users. The sooner that lawmakers and regulators address these barriers to competition (and thus innovation), the better for everyone.

item.title: Is Genocide Being Redefined to Indict Israel?
item.description: Given that the academic consensus on genocide recognizes only a handful of cases, it would be quite shocking for Israel – a country born from the ashes of the Holocaust – to be found guilty of the "crime of all crimes." Yet by massaging the meaning of the term, that is precisely what its critics are seeking to do.

item.title: Bolsonaro and Trump Have Revealed the Biggest Threat to Democracy
item.description: US President Donald Trump and former Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro are emblematic of the contemporary era of competitive authoritarianism, and both attempted to overturn the result of a democratic election by inciting violence among their supporters. So why is one on trial and the other is back in power?

item.title: Switzerland Must Choose Press Freedom Over Bank Secrecy
item.description: As rising geopolitical risks increasingly threaten the stability of the global financial system, investigative journalists and whistleblowers have never been more essential. But Switzerland stands in their way by criminalizing the disclosure of client data – regardless of motive or public interest.

item.title: Max Weber’s Lessons for Democracies Under Siege
item.description: Amid the chaos of the 1918-19 Munich Revolution, the sociologist Max Weber delivered an urgent warning about the perils of demagoguery, fanaticism, and charismatic leaders who confuse conviction with sound judgment. His words fell on deaf ears then, but they remain eerily relevant.

item.title: Century Bonds Could Transform Development Finance
item.description: If traditional donor grants have become politically toxic or financially burdensome for rich countries, why don't they instead issue 100-year, ultra-low-interest bonds to multilateral development banks? This simple idea is neither radical nor unprecedented, and it would be a game-changer for developing economies.

item.title: AI Must Not Ignore Human Rights
item.description: As US tech companies ramp up their international dealmaking, with strong backing from the Trump administration, safeguards to ensure that investments and business practices do not violate human rights are nowhere to be found. Will America abandon its core principles in the name of "winning the AI race"?

item.title: The World Needs a Medical-Research Overhaul
item.description: As matters stand, medical-research agendas and standards are largely dictated by funders in the Global North, even when dealing with diseases that primarily affect the Global South. This approach is not only unfair; it leads to worse health outcomes.

item.title: ASEAN at a Crossroads
item.description: In a time of global fragmentation, ASEAN’s remarkable stability reflects its commitment to open trade, regional cooperation, and active non-alignment. By rejecting unilateral trade measures and retaliatory tariffs, the bloc offers an alternative to great-power politics and protectionism.

item.title: The Failure of Anti-Austerity Populism
item.description: In the aftermath of the 2008 global financial crisis, many economists embraced the argument that governments could borrow freely without long-term consequences. But post-pandemic inflation and higher interest rates have shattered that narrative, exposing anti-austerity economics for the dangerous illusion it was all along.

item.title: The Limits of Xi and Putin’s “No-Limits” Partnership
item.description: Despite Russia's obvious economic dependence on China, the Chinese are not yet dictating outcomes, and Russia is not acting like a junior partner. Political, historical, and geographical factors on each side ensure that nothing about the relationship will be simple or straightforward.

item.title: Why Do Populist Strongmen Love Low Interest Rates?
item.description: The short-term popularity of populist policies can help win elections even as they undermine long-term economic growth. Since this approach inevitably delivers bad economic outcomes over time, populist leaders need low interest rates to prevent their supporters from recognizing how misguided their policies are until it is too late.

item.title: Trump Brings the Incarceration Game to America
item.description: By targeting critics like Federal Reserve Board member Lisa Cook, US President Donald Trump threatens to turn the law into a tool of political repression. What starts as retaliation against a handful of perceived political opponents can quickly escalate, destabilizing society and undermining democratic governance.

item.title: Attacking the Federal Reserve Is Self-Defeating
item.description: President Donald Trump's no-holds-barred campaign for lower interest rates could easily lead to prolonged high US inflation, which would undermine his administration’s goal of boosting home ownership and creating more good jobs. On the contrary, it would undermine prosperity for most Americans.

item.title: Putin’s “Negotiations” Are a Trap
item.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin’s objectives in Ukraine remain as genocidal as ever. The only reason he is expressing an openness to talks is because he wants to reduce international support for Ukraine and demobilize Ukrainians by giving them a false sense of hope.

item.title: Europe Needs a Euro Stablecoin
item.description: The European Central Bank’s strategy for achieving payments autonomy centers on a “digital euro,” which would effectively replace physical cash in the eurozone. But the digital euro's impact would be limited to retail payments and would not substantially increase the euro’s share of international transactions or foreign reserves.

item.title: Is Trump the President of Europe?
item.description: Europe's "strategy" of flattering Donald Trump and abasing itself is not working. Rather than continuing to rely on a deliberately unreliable partner, European leaders must devise their own plan for confronting Russian aggression.

item.title: The Myth of American Deindustrialization
item.description: However politically convenient narratives about the United States "abandoning" manufacturing may be, the reality is more complex and less gloomy than many assume. In fact, US manufacturing has not disappeared, but it did internationalize as American companies pursued higher-value opportunities at home.
